synonyms: open-heart  surgery in adults  cardiac rehabilitation
description: Open-heart  surgery is defined as any surgical procedure that requires the thoracic cavity to be cut open and surgery is performed on the heart muscle, valves, arteries, or other parts of the heart. Procedures typically involve the use of a cardiopulmonary bypass machine (“heart lung machine”) to maintain circulation while the heart is not beating

Cardiac rehabilitation is a medically supervised program designed to optimize the physical, psychological, and social functioning of patients with cardiovascular disease (CVD) as well as to stabilize, slow, or reverse the progression of the underlying disease processes, reducing mortality and disability –Cardiac rehabilitation programs are important in order to maximize the patient’s functional outcomes to allow them to return to work, their social roles, and/or their recreational activities. Cardiac rehabilitation starts in the hospital, with a focus on early mobilization, dietary instructions, and medication management(1) -Patients may continue their rehabilitation program in a short-stay  acute care setting if they are considered stable, but are unable to perform their basic household tasks at home. In this setting, patients are recommended a self-directed  walking program -Physical training exercises are given at the end of a patient’s convalescence. Patient undergoes functional exercise testing, then is prescribed training exercises. Exercise prescription should indicate the type of exercises, intensity levels, frequency, and duration of exercises -Aerobic exercise sessions should begin with a warm-up phase of 2–5 minutes at low intensity. Patients may begin a strength training or circuit training program with resistance exercises if theyhave good left ventricular function
indications: Candidates for CABG surgery typically have coronary artery disease that involves the left main coronary artery, or disease of three or more arteries –CABG surgery is indicated to improve circulation to the myocardium and relieve symptoms of angina
Candidates for valvular replacement or repair typically have valvular stenosis and/or regurgitation (incompetence)

Cardiac rehabilitation is indicated after open-heart  surgery, including CABG surgery and valvular intervention, to –increase peak VO2 while improving cardiovascular response at submaximal levels –increase ischemic threshold –improve left ventricular function –increase coronary collaterals –improve serum lipids –decrease serum catecholamines –decrease platelet aggregation and increase fibrinolysis –improve psychological status –improve knowledge of cardiac risk factors

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. Insurance coverage for medically supervised cardiac rehabilitation varies from state to state and between companies. Some policies cover only a limited number of outpatient sessions while others cover an entire 12-week  program. No specific special agencies are applicable for this condition

Presentation/signs and symptoms –The most common open-heart  surgery procedure is median sternotomy(2) -The surgeon accesses the heart by cutting through and retracting the sternum at its midline. Typically, no muscles are cut -In the acute phase, patients present with a sutured sternotomy incision; the sternum is wired together -The heart and lungs are stopped when the great vessels are cannulated for the cardiopulmonary bypass -Decreased cerebral perfusion secondary to atrial fibrillation and hypoxia due to atelectasis may occur due to the cannulation of the vessels or stopping the lungs. These patients may present with short-term  cognitive impairments -The most commonly harvested vessels for bypass grafting are the saphenous veins from the legs and the internal mammary arteries from the chest wall -Patients may have long leg incisions or several small incisions depending on technique used -Elastic stocking may be worn postoperatively -There are several different procedures that may be performed to repair valves, including valvuloplasty and patching. Two kinds of valves are used for valve replacement: -Mechanical valves – usually made from materials such as plastic, carbon, or metal -Biological valves – made from animal tissue (xenograft) or taken from the human tissue of a donated heart (allograft) –Acute-phase  postoperative open-heart  surgery patients typically present with incisional pain, decreased ability to take a deep breath or effectively cough, decreased mobility, and decreased endurance –After hospital discharge, open-heart  surgery patients typically have decreased cardiac symptoms, but deconditioning and limitations in functional abilities persist Surgical Indications, Contraindications, & Complications

contraindications precautions to test: The examination should be terminated if the patient experiences any cardiac symptoms
A significant change in vital signs would indicate need for termination of the exam; the physician should be notified
If the patient is experiencing discomfort or difficulty with breathing with any movement, that particular activity and, possibly, the exam, should be terminated and the physician should be notified
Exercise testing is contraindicated when systolic blood pressure (BP) is greater than 220 mmHg and/or diastolic BP is greater than 120 mmHg

overall contraindications precautions: The cardiac rehabilitation program must be individualized to each patient’s needs(1)
Post-revascularization  patients may have low ejection fractions and heart failure, making it necessary to closely monitor them(1)

In the first 4-6 weeks after open-heart  surgery (depending on surgeon), sternal precautions are recommended to allow the sternum to heal.(18) Patients should avoid using arms to push up from sitting to standing reaching backward lift arms above 90 degrees lifting more than 5 pounds or 2kg pushing or pulling forcefully with arms being assisted by persons pulling on their arms
Monitor for signs/symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Describe patient’s preoperative history of cardiac disease. Document date and type of surgery and stage of heart disease at that time

course of treatment.medical management: Document hospital course. Average hospital stay after uncomplicated open-heart  surgery is 57 days. Is the patient being treated for any complications related to surgery?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Preoperative medications for heart failure, arrhythmias, hypertension, and endocarditis are usually continued after surgery. Adjustments are made as needed Medications may include ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, diuretics Antiarrhythmic drugs may be prescribed to reduce postoperative arrhythmias Patients with mechanical valves are placed on anticoagulant therapy for the rest of their lives During the first 3 postoperative months, a vitamin K antagonist is recommended(3) Patients may be treated with aspirin(3) Post-transplant  patients are typically on immunosuppressant medications  High-dose  steroids in the perioperative period may reduce maximum work output and oxygen uptake, resulting in higher than normal perceived exertion Pain medications are usually prescribed during the acute postoperative period Inquire about their effectiveness for controlling pain Patients with recent CABG may be prescribed low-dose  bisoprolol with ivabradine in order to improve functional capacity, enhance systolic function, and minimize diastolic dysfunction(13)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Postoperative testing typically includes:
Laboratory tests, especially regarding anticoagulation (INR), intravascular hemolysis and inflammation, red and white
blood cell count, Creactive  protein (CRP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), electrolytes, creatinine/glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
Imaging studies may also be performed
Echocardiography to check for valve function, pericardial effusion, left and right ventricular function, diameter of the inferior vena cava

Transesophageal echocardiography may be a routine procedure post valve surgery to check for occluded motion, prosthetic valve thrombosis or vegetations, perivalvular leaks, left atrial thrombi, or residual regurgitation
Pulmonary function testing may be done in patients with dyspnea, especially in presence of comorbid lung disease
A submaximal exercise test may be administered at hospital discharge
Maximal or submaximal cardiac stress testing may be performed to evaluate the heart and vascular system during exercise
ECG, BP, and oxygen saturation are monitored while patient exercises, typically on treadmill or stationary exercise bicycle
Cardiopulmonary exercise capacity may be assessed using spiroergometry(3)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help The use of foot reflexology was found to reduce the length of ventilator weaning time in patients who had undergone openheart  surgery when compared to simple surface touching (placebo) and control (routine care only)(7)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: If angina or dyspnea occurs, what activities bring on the symptoms? Are they eased with rest?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Ask about feelings of pressure or tightness
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale can be used to rate exercise intensity
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Acute and chronic sleep disturbances are common after open-heart  surgery and may last several months. Does patient experience orthopnea?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., angina pectoris, dyspnea)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Any history of respiratory compromise, dyspnea, cough? Is supplemental oxygen in use? Is patient able to take deep breaths and cough effectively? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe  ___________________________ -Patient’s inability to self-monitor  his/her heart rate (HR) may be a limiting factor for participation in an exercise program -Difficulty concentrating is common after open-heart surgery, and may continue for 46 weeks(2)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any history of MI? Any prior cardiac surgery? Has patient had prior exercise therapy?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient employed? What does the job require? Does the patient participate in recreational activity? Any hobbies? Inquire about smoking
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document prior and current functional level as reported by patient and family -Heart surgery may resolve cardiac disability, but preoperative functional limitations may have resulted in general muscle weakness, depression, and/or anxiety, making a comprehensive approach necessary(1) -Prolonged deconditioning is common in patients who receive heart transplants(1)
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Has the home environment been assessed by a professional?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Calculate BMI; obesity is a risk factor for cardiac disease
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient currently utilize assistive or adaptive devices? If so, are they appropriate? Are new devices indicated? –Sternal precautions may preclude use of crutches
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic sitting and standing balance. Use the Berg Balance Scale (BBS)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Monitor the following at rest, in sitting, in standing, with ADLs, during and after gait, and after a rest period: -BP, heart sounds, HR, rating of perceived exertion (RPE) -ECG for abnormal heart rhythm -O2 saturation values; should be > 95% at rest but may vary by individual -Changes in symptoms -Monitor exertion levels using the Borg RPE Scale and dyspnea scale
Functional capacity tests may include the 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) and 10-meter  incremental shuttle-walk test
Auscultate lungs for abnormal breath sounds as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Check radial and dorsalis pedis pulsesAssess for appropriate lifting techniques, appropriate breathing when lifting, and compliance with weight restrictionsIn acute phase during hospital stay, transfers and functional mobility are often impaired. Assess as indicated; may utilize the FIM assessment or Timed Up and Go (TUG) test –While sternal precautions are in effect, adapted techniques for moving from lying to sitting, sitting to lying, and standing up may need to be implemented –Weight-bearing  through arms should be minimized
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for abnormalities and need for assistive device. Document any shortness of breath, pallor, cyanosis, or diaphoresis during ambulation. Provide immediate rest if these should occur. Document vital signs before, during, and immediately following ambulation. Document time required to recover to normal resting values. Safety may be assessed using Dynamic Gait Index (DGI). The 6MWT can be used
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Perform gross assessment of upper and lower extremity muscle strength using manual muscle testing (MMT) to identify any existing areas of weakness. Resisted MMT may need to be delayed depending on physician’s orders. Valsalva maneuver should be avoided
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect for edema in the extremities and any signs of DVT
Inspect skin for any signs of bruising or hematoma
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess sitting and standing posture for any deviations. Shoulder protraction and thoracic rounding (flexion) are common postoperatively. Note any asymmetrical positioning of the scapula and trunk
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess trunk and upper limb active ROM as indicated. In patients with leg incisions, assess lower limb ROMIdentify tasks patient has difficulty performing; determine if decreased endurance limits self-care  activities. Monitor and document ECG changes and vital signs before, during, and after ADLs
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Stress tests -Protocols have been developed for multistage testing. The most common treadmill test is the Bruce protocol(4) -Consists of 5 stages -Treadmill speed and grade are changed every 3 minutes -Speed increases from 1.7 mph to 5.0 mph -Grade increases from 10% to 18% -Monitored by ECG and closely observed during exercise and recovery -The principles of stress testing include(4) -changing the work load by increasing the speed and/or grade of a treadmill or the resistance of a bicycle ergometer -an initial workload that is low compared to the anticipated aerobic threshold -termination of test at onset of symptoms or a definable abnormality on ECG -measurement of maximum oxygen consumption -Termination of stress test occurs with -presence of progressive angina -a significant drop in systolic BP in response to increasing workload -lightheadedness, confusion, pallor, cyanosis, nausea, or peripheral circulatory insufficiency -abnormal ECG responses -excessive rise in BP -subject wishing to stop
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess orientation to person, place, time, and situation. The Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) may be performed –Cognitive decline following cardiac surgery has been reported.(3) Short-term  neuropsychological changes should be differentiated from long-term  cognitive decline persisting more than 3 postoperative months(3) –Cognitive decline in long-term,  outpatient follow-up  patients may be attributed to aging, new cerebral diseases (e.g., Alzheimer’s), or the influence of cerebrovascular risk factors rather than the operation itself(3)

contraindications precautions: Resting systolic BP > 200 mmHg or resting diastolic BP > 100 mmHg
Body mass increase of ≥ 4 lbs (1.8 kg) over the course of 1 to 3 days
Ischemia that is significant at low work rates
Further reduction in exercise tolerance or dyspnea at rest or upon exertion over the last few days
Regurgitant valvular heart disease necessitating surgery

Other absolute contraindications -Symptoms and signs of congestion, unstable HF, or New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class IV -Exercise-training-induced -myocardial ischemia -hypotension -nonsustained or sustained ventricular tachycardia -uncontrolled atrial fibrillation -Active inflammatory disease -Cerebrovascular or musculoskeletal disease preventing exercise testing or training -Severe obstructive lung disease leading to arterial oxygen desaturation -Thyroid dysfunction, hypo-  or hyperkalemia, hypovolemia
other: Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
All patients should obtain their cardiologist’s clearance before participating in an exercise program
High-risk  patients or those who need other intensive interventions may require an inpatient cardiac rehabilitation program(1)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Patients should undergo cardiopulmonary exercise testing prior to initiating a therapeutic program
Avoid Valsalva maneuver (encourage normal breathing pattern)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association guidelines recommend that all eligible patients participate in cardiac rehabilitation following CABG surgery. This includes early ambulation during hospitalization, outpatient prescriptive exercise training, and education(6) Patients post open-heart  surgery, who are in acute phase, for early mobility and postoperative education. Patients post hospital discharge who have been referred for cardiac rehabilitation after completion of exercise testing to reduce cardiac risk and improve physical functioning and quality of life
prognosis: Patients at high risk for postoperative complications after valve intervention include those with(3) –left ventricular dysfunction –NYHA classes III and IV –concomitant CABG surgery –preoperative arrhythmias
Patients at high risk for postoperative complications after CABG surgery include those with –mitral valve disease –history of atrial fibrillation –COPD
Older age and male sex are independent risk factors for complications(3)

Depression can directly impact a patient’s ability to maximize his or her success with cardiac rehabilitation. Patients who present with preoperative depressive symptoms and postoperative worsening of these symptoms are more likely to report lower physical and psychosocial function and poorer quality of life following CABG surgery compared to individuals who do not have depressive symptoms(6)

Results of a 2016 retrospective study suggest that post heart transplantation patients who participated in an early cardiac rehabilitation program had a survival rate of 98%, 88% and 82% at 1-, 5-, and 10-year  follow-up(14)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Cardiac rehabilitation typically involves a multidisciplinary team. Team members may include cardiologist/cardiovascular surgeon physiatrist internist rehabilitation nurse nurse educator registered dietician physical therapist occupational therapist exercise physiologist social worker psychologist/psychiatrist recreational therapist case manager chaplain vocational counselor smoking cessation program
other considerations: Mental health issues –Depression has been reported in up to 60% of open-heart surgery patients –The American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association guidelines recommend cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or collaborative care for patients with clinical depression following CABG surgery in order to reduce the effects of depression(6)

Preoperative tests and training –The 5 meter walk test (5MWT) as an evaluation of gait speed prior to open-heart  surgery was found to predict hospital length of stay in 252 patients in a suburban hospital in the United States(8) -Patients with a hospital stay > 7 days were found to have slower gait speed as measured by 5MWT, increased occurrence of an assistive device, and a greater number of ICU admissions –Pulmonary rehabilitation prior to open-heart  surgery may result in fewer complications after heart surgery(9) -Based on an RCT of 60 patients in Iran in which the experimental group received pulmonary rehabilitation before and after surgery and the control group received only pulmonary rehabilitation after surgery -Pulmonary rehabilitation consisted of deep breathing exercises, use of incentive spirometer, neck and shoulder mobilization exercises, muscular tension exercises, and shoulder strengthening exercises (protraction/retraction) -Outcome measures that were significantly better in experimental group were predicted forced vital capacity, predicted peak flow indices of spirometry indicator, PCO2 index, and mean oxygen saturation

Authors of a research study conducted in Japan have suggested that preoperative nutritional status can be used as an independent predictor of postoperative rehabilitation recovery in patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery. Those patients who were considered to have a higher Geriatric Nutritional Risk Index (GNRI) demonstrated high scores on handgrip strength, knee extensor muscle strength, Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB), and 6MWT compared to those with a lower GNRI(15)
treatment summary: The American Heart Association and the American Association of Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Rehabilitation recommend that cardiac rehabilitation programs consist of several core components, including baseline patient assessment, nutritional counseling, risk management (e.g., lipid levels, hypertension, weight, diabetes, and smoking), psychosocial management, physical activity counseling, and exercise training(5)

The American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association cardiac rehabilitation guidelines are as follows:(6) –Education and supervised exercise programs should begin 4 to 8 weeks post-CABG  surgery and should be conducted 3 times a week for 3 months  –Exercise training is an important adjunct to dietary modifications

Exercise guidelines –General recommendations are that adults perform 30 minutes of moderate-intensity  (3-6 METs) activity 5 days/week or 20 minutes of vigorous activity (> 6 METs) 3 days/week or a combination of moderate and vigorous activity(4) -The 30 minutes of moderate-intensity  activity can be continuous or accumulated in smaller bouts of at least 10 minutes each(4) -For older adults (> age 65) or adults ages 50 to 65 with chronic health conditions, the criteria for moderate and vigorous intensity are adjusted to a 10-point  scale, rather than MET level. Zero is sitting and 10 is working as hard as one can. Moderate intensity would be 5–6 and vigorous would be 7–8(4) –General principles for cardiac rehabilitation programs(4) -Inpatient phase -Occurs in the hospital after the cardiovascular status is stable; generally lasts 3–5 days -Includes risk education, self-care  activities, and progress from sitting to standing to minimize deconditioning (days 1–3) -Orthostatic challenge to the cardiovascular system is usually introduced on days 3–5, by means of supervised ambulation monitored with ECG -Preparation for discharge may include stair climbing and other skills needed for life at home -Outpatient phase -Typically initiated after healing has occurred and a symptom-limited  stress test has been performed -The exercise is predominantly aerobic -The initial intensity of activity may be as low as 40–60%  of the maximum HR or 40–70%  of the functional capacity defined in METs -Duration may start at 10–15  minutes and progress to 30–60  minutes as patient’s status improves -Each session should include warm-up  and cool-down  periods -Mode of exercise is usually continuous, using large muscle groups, such as stationary bike or walking -Circuit – interval exercise may be used -Advantages include that patients may perform more physical work, exercise at a lower rate of perceived exertion, and exercise at a higher intensity so that fitness improves faster -Weight training may be initiated -Resistive exercise should not produce ischemic symptoms associated with an increase in HR or BP -Progression of the workload should occur when there have been three consecutive sessions during which the peak HR is below the target HR -Independent phase -Recreational activities to maintain the levels gained during supervised training should be introduced -Examples include swimming, hiking, jogging (5 miles per hour), cycling (12 miles per hour), vigorous downhill skiing –Encouraging early enrollment in cardiac rehabilitation appears to be safe if careful, individualized assessments and exercise protocols are developed within an established cardiac rehabilitation program(10) -Based on a review of clinical adverse effects within 6 months of discharge of 250 patients who underwent either CABG surgery or heart valve surgery or had an MI (served as control)

Efficacy studies –Delivery models: Site-supervised  versus home-based  exercise rehabilitation programs -Site-supervised  programs are more appropriate for medically complex patients who may be at high risk for future cardiac events -Site-supervised  programs can facilitate patient education and counseling regarding exercise and lifestyle modification for risk reduction, as well as provide equipment variety, recreational opportunities, and staff assistance -Site-supervised  programs provide greater potential for enhanced adherence and safety –The advantages of a home-based  exercise training program include lower cost, increased convenience and practicality, and potential to promote independence and self-responsibility -For low-to  moderate-risk  patients, medically directed, home-based  exercise rehabilitation and supervised group programs have been shown to have comparable safety and efficacy  -A variety of modern methods of monitoring may be used for patients managed at home, including telephone contact, e-mail,  activity logs, use of pedometers and/or ambulatory tracking devices, video recording, internet, and telephonic ECG monitoring -A hybrid cardiac rehabilitation program was found to be a viable alternative to a hospital-based  cardiac rehabilitation program in remote areas in Iran where there are no appropriate health facilities(11) -Seven hundred eighty patients participated in either a hospital-based  program (n = 585) or a hybrid program (n = 195) -Both groups had common preliminary phase (2–4weeks) with exercise and education. This was followed by an 8-week phase in which the hospital-based  group received education and exercise 3 times a week and the hybrid group received education and exercise once a week, accompanied by a phone call -Similar rates of improvement were seen in exercise capacity and attendance rates were similar

Participation and adherence issues –Not everyone who has open heart surgery is referred for cardiac rehabilitation and not everyone who is referred to cardiac rehabilitation completes the program –Of eligible patients, only approximately 31% participate in cardiac rehabilitation post CABG surgery -Participation is lowest among women, members of racial/ethnic minority groups, socioeconomically disadvantaged patients, and older adults ›Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  concluded that inspiratory muscle training performed before and after surgery was a useful intervention program for patients undergoing cardiac surgery(16)
Eight studies were used for this study

The reviews suggest that inspiratory muscle training was associated with a reduced length of stay in the hospital of -2 days and improvements in inspiratory pressure, forced expiratory volume in one second, and forced vital capacity

The authors also suggest that inspiratory muscle reduces risk of postoperative pulmonary complications . maintenance or prevention: Lifestyle counseling after open-heart  surgery may improve health outcomes and reduce the risk of a new cardiac event(12) Based on an RCT of 500 patients who had open-heart  surgery in Greece Lifestyle counseling was based on recent guidelines provided by the European Society of Cardiology One year after surgery, intervention group was 1.96 times more likely to achieve dietary recommendations, 3.32 times more likely to achieve physical activity recommendations, and 1.34 times more likely to return to work

Regular checkups with a cardiologist should be scheduled once a year for otherwise asymptomatic patients(3) Frequency of checkups for patients with postoperative complications or myopericardial pathologies depends on the clinical situation(3)
patient education: Education is typically provided in the acute care setting to all patients who have undergone open-heart  surgery  Goals of education programs are usually to increase confidence and effectiveness to self-manage  behaviors following discharge An education program to help modify cardiac risk factors should be included(1)

The 2011 American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association Guidelines for CABG Surgery practice state that all patients who are smokers should receive in-hospital  educational counseling and be offered smoking cessation therapy during their hospitalization(6)
